applicant-declaration.description:
You have told us that you are ||/answers/p-applicant-enter-your-name/q-applicant-title|| ||/answers/p-applicant-enter-your-name/q-applicant-first-name|| ||/answers/p-applicant-enter-your-name/q-applicant-last-name|| and you are applying on behalf of yourself.

By submitting this application, you confirm that you understand the following:

  • the information given in this application for compensation is true
  • Criminal Injuries Compensation Authority (CICA) may share and receive information with the following parties for the purposes of processing this application for compensation or verifying information provided:
    • police, prosecutors and ACRO Criminal Records Office, including for the purposes of obtaining a report of the crime and a record of any criminal convictions you may have
    • medical organisations, practitioners, and police medical staff to obtain medical evidence - including medical records and expert reports. CICA will let you know if this is required
    • any other individuals or organisations where necessary to process this application
    • any representative appointed to act for you in the course of this application
  • CICA must be notified immediately of any change in circumstances relevant to this application, including any change of address and information about any other claim or proceedings which may give rise to a separate award or payment in respect of your injuries

Providing wrong or misleading information

If untrue or misleading information is deliberately provided, compensation may be refused and the person(s) responsible may be prosecuted.

Read our privacy notice to see how we use your data (opens in new tab).

Information about appointing a legal or another representative

It is not necessary to appoint a legal or other representative to act on a victim’s behalf. If a representative is appointed at any stage, please be aware that:

  • CICA cannot meet their costs
  • we will only communicate directly with any appointed representative

If we make an award, we will pay it only to the victim or their legal representative. This is unless the application has been made on behalf of:

  • an adult who cannot manage their own financial affairs
  • a child who is under 18 years of age

It is our general policy to put an award for a child in an interest-earning deposit account until they reach the age of 18.

If a monetary award is to be made and there is a dispute about outstanding legal fees, it is our policy to retain the disputed amount until the dispute has been resolved.

If it is decided that a representative’s services are no longer required, CICA must be notified in writing as soon as possible.

q-applicant-confirmation-method.title: How should we tell you we've got the application?

oneOf.title: I don't have an email address or UK mobile phone number
oneOf.description: We will not be able to send you a text or an email confirmation. You will only get an on-screen confirmation with a reference number at the end of this application form. You’ll need to make a note of this reference number in case you need to contact us about your application.

errorMessage.maxLength: Email address must be 50 characters or less
errorMessage.format: Enter an email address in the correct format, like name@example.com
Enter a UK mobile phone number, like 07700 900 982 or +44 7700 900 982
errorMessage.maxLength: Telephone number must be 20 characters or less

required.q-applicant-enter-your-telephone-number: Enter a UK mobile phone number

required.q-applicant-confirmation-method: Select how you want to get your confirmation message

invalidExamples.q-applicant-enter-your-telephone-number: not a UK mobile phone number

required.q-applicant-who-are-you-applying-for: Select who you are applying for

applicant-impact-on-you.title: About the crime
applicant-impact-on-you.description:
We’re going to ask you:

  • when and where the crime happened
  • which police force investigated the crime

This helps us get the information we need to make a decision about your claim.

Support after a crime

You can get practical or emotional support (opens in new tab) after a crime.

There is different practical or emotional support if you live in Scotland (opens in new tab).

q--was-the-crime-reported-to-police.title: Was the crime reported to the police?

dont-know-if-crime-reported.description:
{% from "components/details/macro.njk" import govukDetails %}{% set templateHtml %}{% include 'contact.njk' %}{% endset %}{{ govukDetails({summaryText: "I do not know if the crime was reported to the police",html: '

If you do not know if the crime was reported to the police, call 101 to speak to your local police station. They can help you with this.

'})}}

required.q--was-the-crime-reported-to-police: Select yes if the crime was reported to the police

q--when-was-the-crime-reported-to-police.title: When was the crime reported to the police?
q--when-was-the-crime-reported-to-police.description: For example, 31 12 2022. You can enter an approximate date.

errorMessage.format: Enter the date the crime was reported to police and include a day, month and year

additional-info-help-text.description:
{% from "components/details/macro.njk" import govukDetails %}{{ govukDetails({summaryText: "Help with when it was reported",html: '

If you enter an approximate date or if you reported the crime on more than one occasion, you can provide additional details later in this claim.

'})}}

required.q--when-was-the-crime-reported-to-police: Enter the date the crime was reported to the police

q--whats-the-crime-reference-number.title: What's the crime reference number?
q--whats-the-crime-reference-number.description: This is the number the police gave the crime when it was reported. We need this to get information from the police about the crime.

errorMessage.maxLength: Crime reference number must be 30 characters or less

i-dont-know-the-crime-reference.description:
{% from "components/details/macro.njk" import govukDetails %}{{ govukDetails({summaryText: "Help with the crime reference number",html: '

If there is more than one crime reference number, you can add these numbers to the ‘additional information’ section at the end of the application.

details.myself:
{% from "components/details/macro.njk" import govukDetails %}{{ govukDetails({summaryText: "Help with why we ask about this application not being sent before now",html: '

If you were an adult at the time of the crime (18 years or older)

The application must be sent as soon as is reasonably practicable and in any event, no later than 2 years after the crime.

If you were a child at the time of the crime (under 18 years old)

The application must be received:

  • on or before your 20th birthday, if the crime was reported to police before your 18th birthday
  • within 2 years of the crime first being reported to police, if the incident was reported on or after your 18th birthday

Extending the time limits

We can only extend the time limits where:

  • due to exceptional circumstances, the application could not be made earlier (for example, where illness or injuries stopped you applying)

and

  • the evidence provided to support the application means it can be decided without further extensive enquiries

You may have to provide evidence to support any reason for a delay in applying. This evidence may include a letter from your GP or other medical professional.

Any evidence to support your application should:

  • show why this application could not have been made earlier and explain the entire period of the delay
  • provide us with enough information to make a decision on this application without the need for further extensive enquiries

'})}}

{{ govukPanel({ titleText: "Application submitted", html: html })}}

Thank you for submitting this application.

Send proof you can apply on the victim’s behalf

This proof can be one of the following documents:

  • the victim’s full birth certificate
  • adoption documents
  • a parental responsibility agreement
  • a court order

You should copy the document in one of these ways to send to us:

  • take a photo
  • scan a copy
  • make a photocopy

You should email your documents to us at centraladminaction@cica.gov.uk.

If you cannot send these documents by email, you can post them to us at:

Criminal Injuries Compensation Authority

10 Clyde Place

Buchanan Wharf

Glasgow

G5 8AQ

United Kingdom

What happens next

We will:

  • ask the police for evidence
  • ask for medical information if required
  • ask you for more information if we need it
  • make a decision
  • send our decision letter by post

We aim to make a decision within 12 months but it can take longer. We may have to wait until there’s enough information about the victim's injuries and recovery.

Read our Customer Charter

{{ govukWarningText({ text: "You must inform us immediately if any of the information you have given us changes, especially your address, telephone number or email address.", iconFallbackText: "Warning" }) }}

Sending updated information about your application

You should send us any updates using our contact form.

If any information in your application changes, you need to contact us immediately to let us know. This may include:

  • your contact or personal details change
  • you stop using or change representative
  • you get compensation or money from any other sources after you apply in relation to the incident
  • you have new information to add to your application
  • information you provided previously has changed

Send an update about your application

Contact us

As we've only received this application, we will now carry out necessary initial enquiries relating to this. Unless you've anything new to add or update in the application, we kindly ask that you wait for us to contact you.

{{ govukDetails({ summaryText: "View the different ways to contact CICA", html: contact })}}

Help us improve this service

You can complete a short survey to help us improve this service.

It does not ask for any details about your case and has no effect on your application.

Tell us what you think of our service (opens in new tab) (takes 10 minutes)

description.myself:
We're going to ask:

  • the offender's name (if you know it)
  • if you have contact with the offender

This is so we can make sure the offender would not benefit from any compensation you may be entitled to.

We will never contact the offender.

details-context.description:
We're going to ask how the crime affected your mental health.

This helps us decide if you'll get a payment for mental injury.

Disabling mental injury

We can only pay for a 'disabling mental injury' that:

  • makes it much harder to do things you would normally do
  • lasts six weeks or more
  • is confirmed by a diagnosis or prognosis by a clinical psychologist or psychiatrist

You can apply if you do not have a diagnosis yet. We'll tell you what medical evidence you'll need. This may be a copy of your medical record, a GP report or a specialist report.
details-context.description_someone-else:
We're going to ask how the crime affected their mental health.

This helps us decide if they get a payment for mental injury.

Disabling mental injury

We can only pay for a 'disabling mental injury' that:

  • makes it much harder to do things they would normally do
  • lasts six weeks or more
  • is confirmed by a diagnosis or prognosis by a clinical psychologist or psychiatrist

You can apply if they do not have a diagnosis yet. We'll tell you what medical evidence they'll need. This may be a copy of their medical record, a GP report or a specialist report.

details-context.description:
We're going to ask for some details about your treatment

We'll use these to understand:

  • if your GP is aware of your injuries
  • who has evidence of your injuries

We often have to ask your GP or other health service provider for evidence about your injuries and treatment. We will let you know if we need to do this.
details-context.description_someone-else:
We're going to ask for some details about their treatment.

We'll use these to understand:

  • if their GP is aware of their injuries
  • who has evidence of their injuries

We often have to ask their GP or other health service provider for evidence about their injuries and treatment. We will let you know if we need to do this.

describe-incident-info.title: Crime description
describe-incident-info.description:
It may help us process this application more quickly if you give us a brief description of the crime. It helps us to:

  • understand what happened
  • reduce the amount of additional information we need as part of the application

If you'd prefer not to give us a brief description of the crime, it will not affect the outcome of this application.

p--context-crime-ref-no.title: You'll need to give us the crime reference number as part of this application
p--context-crime-ref-no.description:
The police give every crime a reference number when it's reported. This is called a crime reference number. You'll need to give us this crime reference number as part of this application so you should make sure you know it.

If you do not know your crime reference number, call 101 to speak to your local police station. They'll be able to tell you the crime reference number. You'll need to give them some details about the crime to help them find the correct case.

If you do not have the crime reference number to hand, you can continue with your application but you'll need to enter it later.

applicant-additional-info.title: Additional information
applicant-additional-info.description:
We're going to ask you if you want to provide any more details about this claim

This can be information that did not fit the questions you have been asked, such as additional:

  • crime reference numbers
  • offender names
  • locations

This helps us get the information we need to make a decision about this claim.

context-crime-impact.description:
We're going to ask you questions about:

  • how your daily life has been impacted by your injuries
  • how long the effects of your injuries are likely to last
  • your ability to work now and in future

The answers you give help build an understanding of how your injuries have affected you.

In sending this application, you will be considered for compensation for loss of earnings and special expenses.

Loss of earnings

If the medical evidence shows the injuries result in very limited or no capacity to work, you may get a loss of earnings payment.

Special expenses

If you cannot work for more than 28 weeks or are likely to lose earnings because of how severe the injuries are, or are incapacitated to a similar extent, you may receive a special expenses payment.

Both of these payment types are to compensate for any financial losses you have because of your injuries.
context-crime-impact.description_someone-else:
We're going to ask you questions about:

  • how the victim's daily life has been impacted by their injuries
  • how long the effects of their injuries are likely to last
  • their ability to work now and in future

The answers you give help build an understanding of how their injuries have affected them.

In sending this application, the victim will be considered for compensation for loss of earnings and special expenses.

Loss of earnings

If the medical evidence shows the injuries result in very limited or no capacity to work, they may get a loss of earnings payment.

Special expenses

If the victim cannot work for more than 28 weeks or is likely to lose earnings because of how severe the injuries are, or is incapacitated to a similar extent, they may receive a special expenses payment.

Both of these payment types are to compensate for any financial losses they have because of their injuries.

context-crime-impact.title: The impact the injuries have had

You need to prove you have parental responsibility for the claimant to apply.

To prove this, you'll need relevant documents your name is on, such as:

Understand more about parental responsibility (opens in new tab).

"})}}

mainapplicant.child:
We need proof so we know you have the right to apply on the victim's behalf.

This proof can be:

  • the victim's full birth certificate
  • adoption documents
  • a parental responsibility agreement
  • a court order

pregnancy-context.description:
We need to ask questions about pregnancy related to the crime. These questions may be difficult to answer or may not be relevant to you.

By answering them, it ensures you are considered for all correct compensation from us. This helps us better understand the case and if we need to ask for more evidence from you.

Help and support

The following links open in a new tab.

You can get practical and emotional support after a crime. Visit Victim and Witness information(opens in new tab) if you’re in England and Wales. Or support as a victim or witness of crime(opens in new tab) in Scotland.

description.myself:
We’re going to ask you about specific payments you may have had to make, or will make, because of the injuries caused by the crime.

We can only consider certain expenses – known as “special expenses” – and will ask you questions about these.

We’ll consider this application for special expenses if you have experienced one of the following for more than 28 weeks due to your injuries:

  • lost earnings
  • lost earning capacity
  • or been incapacitated to a similar extent

The 28 weeks can be a single period of time or cover several periods of time since the crime. Any special expenses payment will include payment for the first 28 weeks from when you were injured.

Providing evidence of expenses

We may ask you to provide evidence:

  • of any expenses incurred or expected
  • that the products or services are not available free of charge
  • that they were needed as a result of the injuries

The 28 weeks can be a single period of time or cover several periods of time since the crime. Any special expenses payment will include payment for the first 28 weeks from when they were injured.

description.myself:
We need to know if you have paid, or will need to pay, for any of the following things in the future, as a result of the crime:

  • NHS or other state health services treatments - such as dental or eye care
  • care or supervision - such as someone preparing meals
  • changes to your home - such as installing a stair lift
  • special equipment - such as a wheel chair or adaptations to a car
  • replacing or repairing physical aids - such as a walking stick or glasses
description.capable:
We need to know if the victim has paid, or will need to pay, for any of the following things in the future, as a result of the crime:

  • NHS or other state health services treatments - such as dental or eye care
  • care or supervision - such as someone preparing their meals
  • changes to their home - such as installing a stair lift
  • special equipment - such as a wheel chair or adaptations to a car
  • replacing or repairing physical aids - such as a walking stick or glasses
description.incapable:
We need to know if you or the victim has paid, or will need to pay, for any of the following things in the future, as a result of the crime:

  • NHS or other state health services treatments - such as dental or eye care
  • care or supervision - such as someone preparing their meals
  • changes to their home - such as installing a stair lift
  • special equipment - such as a wheel chair or adaptations to a car
  • replacing or repairing physical aids - such as a walking stick or glasses

We also need to know if you will need to pay for either of the following in the future:

  • costs of administering their affairs if they lack mental capacity to do so
  • fees to the Court of Protection, Public Guardian or Sheriff Court

child.nonDeceased:
We're going to ask for details about the person who has parental responsibility for the victim. This means they have the legal authority to apply on their behalf.

This could be:

  • the victim's birth, step or adoptive parent
  • a person named on a Special Guardianship order
  • the local authority

If you do not have parental responsibility

You can still apply even if you do not have parental responsibility for the victim. If this is the case, we will ask you for the details of someone who does have the parental responsibility to act on behalf of the victim.

This allows us to communicate with this person or organisation after you've sent this application.
child.deceased:
We're going to ask for details about the person who has parental responsibility for the claimant. This means they have the legal authority to apply on their behalf.

This could be:

  • the claimant's birth, step or adoptive parent
  • a person named on a Special Guardianship order
  • the local authority

If you do not have parental responsibility

You can still apply even if you do not have parental responsibility for the claimant. If this is the case, we will ask you for the details of someone who does have the parental responsibility to act on behalf of the claimant.

This allows us to communicate with this person or organisation after you've sent this application.

incapable.nonDeceased:
You've told us the person you're applying for is unable to handle their own affairs in relation to this application.

Therefore, we're going to ask for details about the person who has legal authority to act on behalf of the victim.

This could be:

  • a person appointed by a court
  • a person named on a power of attorney document
  • the local authority

If you do not have legal authority

You can still apply even if you do not have legal authority to act on behalf of the victim. If this is the case, we will ask you for the details of someone who does have the legal authority to act on behalf of the victim.

This allows us to communicate with the person who has authority after you've sent this application.
incapable.deceased:
You've told us the person you're applying for is unable to handle their own affairs in relation to this application.

Therefore, we're going to ask for details about the person who has legal authority to act on behalf of the claimant.

This could be:

  • a person appointed by a court
  • a person named on a power of attorney document
  • the local authority

If you do not have legal authority

You can still apply even if you do not have legal authority to act on behalf of the claimant. If this is the case, we will ask you for the details of someone who does have the legal authority to act on behalf of the claimant.

This allows us to communicate with the person who has authority after you've sent this application.

title.applicant: Were you a close relative of a member of the British Armed Forces living together when the crime happened?
title.proxy: Were they a close relative of a member of the British Armed Forces living together when the crime happened?

details.applicant:
{% from "components/details/macro.njk" import govukDetails %}{{ govukDetails({summaryText: "Help with who qualifies as a close relative of a member of the British Armed Forces",html: "

A person is a close relative of a member of the British Armed Forces if they are living together as part of the same household and is either:

  • their spouse or civil partner
  • their partner (other than a spouse or civil partner) for a continuous period of at least two years immediately before the date of the crime
  • a child aged under 18 of that member of the British Armed Forces or of their spouse, civil partner or partner
  • a child of that member of the British Armed Forces who is financially or physically dependent on that person as a result of a physical or mental disability
"})}}

description.myself:
You may be entitled to claim back money spent on the funeral.

We’re now going to ask you some questions about funeral costs. This includes:

  • if you’re paying any of the funeral costs
  • if anyone else is contributing to the funeral costs
  • the cost of the funeral
  • what type of proof you need to provide and how to send it to us

Funeral costs you may be able to claim

Funeral costs can include:

  • funeral service (including casket, burial or cremation)
  • tombstone
  • memorials
  • flowers
  • newspaper announcements
  • catering and non-alcoholic refreshments
  • costs of transporting the person who died back to their country of origin

You may be able to claim up to £5000.

title.myself: You may need to send proof of funeral costs
title.proxy: You may need to send proof of funeral costs

description.myself:
You may receive a funeral payment of £2,500 once we have confirmed that you're eligible. If the funeral costs are more than £2,500 you may be eligible for a further payment. The total payment cannot be more than £5,000.

You will need to provide proof of payment for costs up to £2,500. In addition, any costs over £2,500 can only be paid if you provide receipts or invoices showing a breakdown of costs. These costs should be reasonable and may include items such as:

  • funeral service (including casket, burial or cremation)
  • tombstone
  • memorials
  • flowers
  • newspaper announcements
  • catering and non-alcoholic refreshments
  • costs of transporting the person who died back to their country of origin

Public funds

If you have already received money from public funds to help pay for funeral costs, you will need to provide details of this as we will need to take this into account when deciding your claim.

Public funds could include:

  • Funeral Expenses Payment (opens in a new tab) from the Department for Work and Pensions if you live in England or Wales
  • Funeral Support Payment (opens in a new tab) from Social Security Scotland if you live in Scotland

summary.title: What do you want to claim?

applicant-claim-type-info.description:
{% from "components/details/macro.njk" import govukDetails %}{{ govukDetails({summaryText: "Other payments that qualifying relatives could be eligible for", html: '

Bereavement payment

Relatives of the person who died who could be eligible for a bereavement payment include:

  • parents
  • children (this includes adult children and children born after the crime happened)
  • a spouse or civil partner who was living in the same household or living apart but financially dependent on the person who died
  • a partner who was living in the same household continuously for at least 2 years immediately before the person died
  • a partner, spouse or civil partner who did not live with the person who died because of ill health

Dependency payment

Relatives who were financially or physically dependent on the person who died who could be eligible for a dependency payment include:

  • all those eligible for a bereavement payment
  • a former spouse or former civil partner

Child’s payment

Children of the person who died could also be eligible for a child’s payment. They must have been under 18 at the time of the person’s death and reliant on them for parental support.

'}) }}

description.applicant:
If you’ve applied before, or someone's applied for you, for injuries related to this crime, we cannot accept another application from you.

If you’re waiting to hear from us

We have your application and are processing it. We'll contact you if we need any more information.

In the majority of cases we make a decision within 12 months, but it can take longer. You may not hear from us during this time, but we are working hard to process your application as quickly as possible.

If your information has changed and you need to let us know, you can contact us to update your existing application.

If you applied in the past but were not successful

We cannot accept another application from you, for injuries related to this crime. You should not apply again.

What to do next

If you want to exit this application, you can close this window or tab. You can still continue, if you would like to.

If you want to exit this application, you can close this window or tab. You can still continue, if you would like to.
